episodeTitle: A Hero Who Freed the Slaves! An Adventurer Tiger!
description: Sixteen years in the past, Queen Otohime advocates for peaceful coexistence between fish-men and humans through petitions, while Fisher Tiger returns from his legendary raid on Mary Geoise where he freed countless slaves. Inspired by Tiger's heroism, Jinbe abandons the Neptune Army to join the newly formed Sun Pirates.

events.title: Queen Otohime's First Appearance
events.description: Queen Otohime is introduced as the compassionate ruler of Ryugu Kingdom, advocating for peaceful coexistence between fish-men and humans. She demonstrates her unwavering belief in bridging the divide between species.
events.significance: Establishes one of the most important figures in Fish-Man Island history and her philosophy of peace and understanding.

quotes.text: Distance is the closure of a person's heart. Only through direct communication can we bridge the divide.
quotes.speaker: Otohime
quotes.context: Otohime explaining her philosophy about human-fish-man relations

events.title: Papaneel's Introduction
events.description: Papaneel, a desperate fish-man robber, attempts to steal money to feed his ten children. He confronts Queen Otohime when she tries to stop him.
events.significance: Demonstrates the poverty and desperation affecting some citizens of Fish-Man Island and sets up Otohime's compassionate response.

events.title: Otohime Demonstrates Observation Haki
events.description: When Papaneel shoots at her, Queen Otohime dodges the bullets with her eyes closed, demonstrating her innate Observation Haki (Kenbunshoku Haki). The Minister of the Right later explains she was born with this rare ability.
events.significance: Reveals that Otohime possesses Observation Haki from birth, showcasing her exceptional spiritual abilities despite her physically fragile body.

events.title: Otohime's Physical Fragility Revealed
events.description: After dodging the bullets, Otohime slaps Papaneel to discipline him. However, her incredibly fragile body causes her hand to suffer a complex fracture from the impact, causing her to scream in pain. Despite this, she lectures Papaneel about his wrongdoing.
events.significance: Highlights the stark contrast between Otohime's spiritual strength and physical weakness, emphasizing her courage and determination.

events.title: Otohime's Petition Campaign
events.description: Queen Otohime gives a passionate speech at Gyoncorde Plaza, encouraging citizens to sign a petition for migration to the surface world and peaceful coexistence with humans. Despite her eloquence, most citizens refuse due to their deep-seated distrust of humans.
events.significance: Establishes Otohime's central mission and the resistance she faces from her own people who have suffered from human prejudice.

quotes.text: We shouldn't judge humans based on the actions of a few. We must try to befriend them and live together on the surface.
quotes.speaker: Otohime
quotes.context: Otohime's plea to the citizens of Fish-Man Island

events.title: Fisher Tiger's Introduction
events.description: Fisher Tiger, a sea bream fish-man adventurer, arrives at Ryugu Palace to meet with King Neptune. His imposing figure and adventurer's reputation precede him as he prepares to reveal something monumental.
events.significance: Introduces one of the most important figures in Fish-Man Island history, whose actions will change the world's view of fish-men forever.

events.title: Tiger Reveals the Mary Geoise Slave Liberation
events.description: Fisher Tiger tells King Neptune that he has freed slaves from Mary Geoise, the holy land of the World Nobles. When Neptune asks what he saw there, Tiger simply responds 'humans,' his face filled with pain and anger. This revelation brings Queen Otohime to tears as she understands the horrors he witnessed.
events.significance: Reveals Fisher Tiger's legendary raid on Mary Geoise and his firsthand experience with the cruelty of slavery, establishing his status as a hero and the trauma that drives him.

quotes.speaker: Fisher Tiger
quotes.context: Tiger's haunting response when asked what he saw at Mary Geoise

events.title: The Ransacking of Mary Geoise Explained
events.description: Through flashback narration, it's revealed that 15 years ago, Fisher Tiger climbed the Red Line with his bare hands and infiltrated Mary Geoise. He ran through the holy land in the middle of the night, freeing every slave he could find regardless of their species - including fish-men, humans, and others. Among those freed were Boa Hancock and her sisters, and later Koala.
events.significance: One of the most significant acts of rebellion against the World Government, establishing Fisher Tiger as a legendary figure and revealing the extent of the slave trade.

events.title: Fish-Man Island Celebrates Tiger's Heroism
events.description: News of Fisher Tiger's raid on Mary Geoise spreads across all of Fish-Man Island. The entire island erupts in celebration, viewing Tiger as a hero who struck back against the humans who had enslaved their people for centuries.
events.significance: Demonstrates the deep impact of Tiger's actions on fish-man society and the long-standing resentment against human oppression.

events.title: Formation of the Sun Pirates
events.description: Fisher Tiger establishes the Sun Pirates, a pirate crew composed primarily of fish-men who were freed from slavery. The crew adopts a sun symbol, which Tiger brands onto all members to cover their slave marks and make it impossible for the World Government to identify former slaves.
events.significance: Creates one of the most important pirate crews in One Piece history and establishes the sun symbol as a mark of freedom and equality.

events.title: Jinbe Joins the Sun Pirates
events.description: Inspired by Fisher Tiger's heroic actions and ideals, Jinbe makes the momentous decision to leave his position in the Neptune Army and join the Sun Pirates. This marks the beginning of Jinbe's journey as a pirate.
events.significance: A pivotal moment in Jinbe's history, setting him on the path that will eventually lead to him becoming a Warlord and later a Straw Hat Pirate.

events.title: Arlong Joins the Sun Pirates
events.description: Arlong and his gang, who had grown up with Jinbe in the Fish-Man District, decide to join Fisher Tiger's Sun Pirates. This alliance brings together some of the strongest fish-men on the island.
events.significance: Establishes Arlong's connection to the Sun Pirates and Fisher Tiger, providing context for his later actions in the East Blue and his complex relationship with Jinbe.

events.title: Macro's Gang Joins the Sun Pirates
events.description: Macro and his subordinates also join the newly formed Sun Pirates, adding to the crew's growing membership of freed fish-men seeking to protect their kind.
events.significance: Expands the Sun Pirates' roster and shows the wide appeal of Fisher Tiger's cause among fish-men.

events.title: Aladine's Introduction
events.description: Aladine, a goatsbeard brotula merman who was formerly enslaved and then freed, appears as one of the members who joins the Sun Pirates. He will later serve as the crew's doctor and first mate.
events.significance: Introduces a key member of the Sun Pirates who represents those freed from slavery.

themes.description: The episode explores the brutal reality of slavery through Fisher Tiger's raid on Mary Geoise and the liberation of countless slaves of all races.
themes.symbolism: The sun symbol represents freedom from bondage and the covering of slave brands symbolizes the attempt to erase the shame and trauma of enslavement.
culturalReferences: The episode draws parallels to real-world slavery and the struggle for civil rights, with Fisher Tiger representing militant liberation and Queen Otohime representing peaceful activism.

themes.description: The episode examines racism from multiple angles: fish-men's distrust of humans based on historical oppression, and the World Nobles' treatment of fish-men as property.
themes.symbolism: The divide between surface and underwater worlds represents the segregation and lack of understanding between races.
culturalReferences: Fisher Tiger has been compared to Malcolm X's more confrontational approach to civil rights, while Otohime represents MLK's philosophy of nonviolent resistance and integration.

themes.description: Otohime and Fisher Tiger represent two different approaches to achieving equality: peaceful petition versus direct action.
themes.symbolism: Otohime's fragile body but strong spirit versus Tiger's physical strength but emotional trauma represents different forms of courage.

themes.description: Despite facing a robber, Otohime shows compassion and seeks to understand his circumstances, embodying her philosophy of understanding over punishment.
themes.symbolism: Otohime breaking her hand while slapping Papaneel represents the personal cost of standing up for principles.

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime expands on some of the emotional reactions and crowd scenes during the celebration of Fisher Tiger's raid.

trivia.fact: This episode adapts portions of chapters 621-622 from the manga.
The episode aired on March 25, 2012 in Japan with an 8.8% TV rating, ranking 7th for that week.
Fisher Tiger's voice actor Kōji Ishii brings gravitas to the character, perfectly conveying both his strength and underlying trauma.
Michiko Neya voices Queen Otohime with a gentle yet determined tone that captures her compassionate yet resolute nature.
The sun symbol of the Sun Pirates was designed to be bold enough to completely cover the Celestial Dragon slave brand.
This episode marks the beginning of a multi-episode flashback arc that explores the tragic history of Fish-Man Island.
